title-group.article-title: Control-oriented premixed charge compression ignition combustion timing model for a diesel engine utilizing flexible intake valve modulation

article-meta.aff: 2Herrick Labs, Purdue University, W. Lafayette, Indiana, USA

author-notes.corresp: Gregory Shaver, Purdue University, 585 Purdue Mall, West Lafayette, IN 47909, USA. Email: gshaver@purdue.edu

abstract.p: This paper describes a simple, analytical, control-oriented model for prediction of combustion timing during premixed charge compression ignition combustion with early fuel injection. The model includes direct dependence on in-cylinder temperature, in-cylinder pressure, and the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction, including the contribution of recirculated exhaust gas, residual burned gas, and backflow during the valve overlap period. The model is extensively validated against experimental premixed charge compression ignition data from a multi-cylinder diesel engine utilizing high-pressure recirculated exhaust gas, variable geometry turbocharging, and flexible intake valve actuation, which allows control over the engine’s effective compression ratio. The results show that across a wide range of input conditions, the model predicts the start of combustion within ±2° crank angle of the experimental values for all but three of the 180 data points (98%+ accuracy), with a root mean square error of 0.86° crank angle. The experimental start of combustion ranges from as early as −19.3° crank angle to as late as +0.6° crank angle by heavily exercising the control actuators, specifically the commanded start of injection timing SOIecm, the intake valve closure timing, and the engine’s air-handling system (recirculated exhaust gas valve position and variable geometry turbocharger position). Analysis is performed to isolate the effects and control authority of each actuator on the ignition delay and start of combustion timing. During these actuator sweeps, the model captures complex relationships and predicts the start of combustion within ±2° crank angle of the experimental values. This premixed charge compression ignition combustion timing model can be coupled with a gas exchange model for control algorithm design and analysis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Premixed charge compression ignition (PCCI) continues to be a promising technology for significant reduction in nitrogen oxides and particulate matter emissions in diesel engines1 while maintaining or improving fuel efficiency.2 Without a ‘direct trigger’ to start the PCCI combustion event as there is in spark-ignition and conventional diesel engines, knowledge or prediction of the combustion timing is more critical. In order to design closed-loop control algorithms for PCCI,3 simplified control-oriented models are desired. Such a model must be computationally efficient for controller design and/or implementation in real-time control.

A large number of previous efforts to model the combustion phasing and/or ignition delay have been undertaken. Wolfer4 used experimental data from a combustion bomb with diesel fuel to show that ignition delay is primarily influenced by pressure and temperature. Wolfer was also the first to introduce the use of an Arrhenius expression as a global representation of collision theory to model ignition delay. This first expression includes inverse dependence on pressure

where P is the mixture pressure, T is the bulk mixture temperature, A is a pre-exponential constant,
E
a
is the activation energy for the fuel,
R
u
is the universal gas constant, and n is a constant. Despite characterizing the primary dependence of ignition delay on temperature and pressure, Wolfer suggested that the probability of molecular collisions is also influenced by the concentrations of fuel, O2, and inert gases.

Using Wolfer’s work as a basis, Sitkei5 modeled the ignition delay as a multi-stage process, incorporating three Arrhenius expressions as in equation (1) in an additive fashion. Henein and Bolt6 also used a form of Wolfer’s expression to examine the effect of common engine operating parameters, such as fuel/air ratio, on the ignition delay period.

Kadota et al.7 used a pressure vessel to study the ignition delay of a single drop of fuel for three fuels (including n-dodecane) over temperature and pressure conditions similar to those in an engine post compression. They introduced the effect of oxygen concentration
[
O
2
]
on the ignition delay in addition to the pressure and temperature as

Fujimoto et al.8 used fuel oil injected into a constant volume combustion bomb and correlated the ignition delay with explicit dependence on oxygen concentration using equation (2), similar to Kadota, but for a larger span of engine-like pressures. They defined two sets of the constants A, m, and n for when the cylinder pressure was in either a low range or high range, as opposed to a single set of constants valid across the entire range of data.

While considering the effects of oxygen-enrichment of the intake air, Lahiri et al.9 extended Fujimoto’s work on including oxygen concentration in the Arrhenius expression by using the fuel/oxygen ratio (F/O, on a mass basis) instead of the more common fuel/air ratio
They also established flammability limits for the in-cylinder mixture as a function of F/O ratio.

As part of a larger detailed combustion model, Hiroyasu et al.10 was the first to include dependence on the fuel/air equivalence ratio
ϕ
in an Arrhenius expression for ignition delay

As the Arrhenius expression became one of the primary ways to model ignition delay, it was used in several different forms and applications. For example, Wan et al.11 used KIVA with a flamelet model to resolve complex kinetics in three dimensions for simulation of the autoignition delay in diesel fuel sprays, using an Arrhenius expression for each differential volume to determine ignition, which is accurate and computationally intensive. A simplified model was derived by Abraham and Bracco12 from a complex three-dimensional model by use of an Arrhenius expression to model radical formation via a source term, which is then used to solve eight species conservation equations simultaneously to predict autoignition. Weisser et al.13 considered the use of a set of three Arrhenius correlations to represent the low-, medium-, and high-temperature kinetics during the ignition delay with 15 fitted constants and was validated against simulations based upon data taken in a spray chamber. An integrated Arrhenius expression with built-in lean and rich flammability limits (captured via dependence on the equivalence ratio) was developed by Morel and Wahiduzzaman,14 and solved numerically. Shaver et al.15 modeled the combustion timing for an engine operating in homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) by using an integrated Arrhenius expression with the top dead center (TDC) assumption to simplify it to an analytical form. Widd et al.16 utilized this TDC assumption to model combustion timing in an HCCI engine with ethanol as the fuel, although use of this TDC assumption does not permit the model to predict a start of combustion (SOC) timing that occurs before TDC, which is common in the experimental direct-injection PCCI data collected in this study.

Several more recent efforts are based on Arrhenius expressions. Aghav et al.17 applied the work of Lahiri to oxygenated biofuels, utilizing the F/O ratio dependence in the Arrhenius expression to characterize the ignition delay in four different engine architectures. Gray and Ryan18 used the dependence on oxygen concentration in equation (2) to investigate the effects of exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) during diesel HCCI combustion. Albrecht et al.19 developed a control model of premixed diesel combustion for control design and simulation that utilizes an Arrhenius expression which is then integrated to determine the ignition delay. A simple, accurate three-stage ignition delay model was developed by Hernandez et al.,20 but included the activation energy
E
a
in the regression fit as a tunable parameter. He et al.21 studied the ignition delay of iso-octane during HCCI combustion, developing a more complex Arrhenius expression with the fuel/oxygen equivalence ratio
ϕ
FO
and the molar percentage of oxygen
N
O
2

with good results. Babajimopoulos et al.22 used this same equation for iso-octane but instead approximated each quantity as its value at TDC to create a more simple, direct relationship between the in-cylinder conditions at TDC and the combustion timing. Hillion et al.23 developed a control-oriented model for diesel HCCI combustion that includes an Arrhenius expression with pressure, temperature, and a burned gas fraction that is integrated to solve for the combustion timing.

Glewen et al.24 experimentally demonstrated the strong influence that the amount of intake O2 has on transient performance during PCCI combustion, and showed that even with constant EGR fraction or EGR flow, the composition of the EGR gas can change during transients, resulting in changes in the amount of intake O2 even after the flows are steady. Other efforts25 have considered the mass of fresh air in the cylinder when modeling the ignition delay, but do not account for in-cylinder diluents, including EGR, residual burned gas, and backflow of exhaust during the valve overlap. The strong influence of intake O2 and presence of large amounts of diluent (up to 60% by mass in this study) in the cylinder motivate new modeling work, specifically the definition and use of a total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction that includes EGR, residual burned gas, and backflow during the valve overlap period. This quantity is used in an Arrhenius expression to capture changes in the amount of both oxygen and diluent in the cylinder.

Several prior studies7,10,18,19,20,22,23 considered integrated Arrhenius expressions for ignition delay to account for the variation of pressure and temperature during the ignition delay period. First derived by Livengood and Wu,26 the relationship between the normalized reaction rate (RR) and the ignition delay while modeling autoignition in engines and rapid compression machines is
which is written more specifically

Again, this is commonly used to account for the variation in pressure and temperature (and any other time-dependent quantities) over the ignition delay period. However, equations in the form of equation (8) must be solved numerically to calculate
τ
id
or SOC, which is undesirable for control-oriented modeling. For the purposes of this work, an analytical version of the Arrhenius expression is desired. The work of Assanis et al.25 defines the average pressure
P
¯
and average temperature
T
¯
over the ignition delay period for direct use in the Arrhenius equation, which yields an analytical equation. These definitions are modified in this study to use variable limits on the average to better represent the wide range of SOC timings possible with PCCI combustion.

Physical and chemical factors other than the temperature, pressure, and concentration of fuel and oxygen as presented above have been shown to influence the ignition delay under certain conditions. Henein and Bolt6 shows the effect of fuel injection pressure, in-cylinder turbulence, and coolant temperature (as a surrogate for heat transfer) on the ignition delay. Caton et al.27 characterized how a fuel’s hydrocarbon chain length and boiling point relate to ignition delay. Kobori et al.28 explores the changes in ignition delay caused by fuel injection pressure, injector nozzle diameter, and cetane number (CN) of the fuel. The effect of the fuel’s cetane number on the autoignition delay is well understood,29–31. Hardenburg and Hase,32 through extensive experimentation on many engine architectures, discovered a hyperbolic relationship between the cetane number and the activation energy
E
a

in J/mole, which is valid for fuels with cetane numbers from 36 to 82. It is acknowledged that many factors can influence the ignition delay process in a direct-injection diesel engine. However, in the interest of developing a control-oriented model for ignition delay that is accurate while as simple as possible, many of these factors such as cetane number, injector geometry, and other fuel properties are considered out of scope for this work.

This study presents a simple, analytical, control-oriented model for prediction of combustion phasing during PCCI combustion with early injection. The contributions of this work include the following.

list-item.p: The model is a single, computationally efficient analytical expression with only three fitted constants that is capable of predicting the combustion timing before and after TDC.

This is the first study to develop a control-oriented model of ignition delay in a diesel engine using an Arrhenius expression that includes dependence on the total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction, calculated from the mass and composition of not only the inducted charge, but also the residual gas and backflow.

In addition to the ignition delay, this study characterizes the electrical and hydraulic delays that occur in the fuel injection system. This allows the model to map directly from the control command SOIecm to the SOC timing.

The model is analytical (and can be used in a state space model) by utilizing the average pressure
P
¯
and average temperature
T
¯
over the ignition delay period (from SOI to SOC) in the Arrhenius expression. As the SOC timing is not known a priori when computing these two averages, a unique, accurate surrogate is developed to represent it for PCCI combustion.

Whereas some of the prior efforts are validated with simulations, experimental data from a combustion bomb or constant-pressure vessel, or data from a single-cylinder test engine, the model developed in this study is extensively validated with 180 experimental PCCI data points from a multi-cylinder engine utilizing high-pressure EGR, variable geometry turbocharging, and a fully flexible variable intake valve actuation system.

The 180 experimental PCCI data points in this study represent the full effective range of actuator positions and commands for PCCI combustion on the testbed, resulting in a large variety of in-cylinder temperatures, pressures, oxygen concentrations, and diluent concentrations. The effective compression ratio (ECR) of the engine is varied between 18:1 and 12:1 by modulation of the intake valve closure (IVC) timing.

This study also examines the relationships and control authority of each of the control actuators or commands – namely, the EGR valve position, variable geometry turbocharger (VGT) position, IVC timing, and commanded SOI – on the ignition delay and SOC timing as well as the model’s predictive performance when each actuator or command is changed individually.

sec.p: To the best of the authors’ knowledge, no prior efforts can be characterized by any more than one of the aforementioned contributions.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: The experimental testbed used in this study is a 2008 Cummins ISB multi-cylinder engine with 6.7 l displacement rated at 261 kW (350 hp). This six-cylinder direct-injection diesel engine has a geometric compression ratio of 17.3:1 and utilizes high-pressure cooled EGR regulated with an electronically controlled EGR valve, a sliding nozzle-type VGT, an air-to-water charge air cooler, and a common-rail injection system. A schematic of the engine architecture is presented in Figure 1.

caption.p: Schematic of Cummins 6.7 l multi-cylinder testbed.

sec.p: A very unique capability of this multi-cylinder testbed is that it is outfitted with a fully flexible electro-hydraulic variable valve actuation (VVA) system that enables cylinder-independent, cycle-to-cycle control of the engine’s valve events. Figure 2 presents a schematic of the VVA system. Currently the intake valve pairs are driven by the VVA system, such that it is possible to change the intake valve opening (IVO) timing, IVC timing, intake valve lift (IVL), and the ramp rates/velocity of the profile on a cycle-to-cycle basis. This study focuses on the use of IVC modulation to vary the ECR of the engine, in an effort to promote advanced combustion modes such as PCCI.

caption.p: Schematic of Purdue VVA system.

sec.p: A Kistler 6067C in-cylinder pressure transducer in tandem with an AVL 365C crankshaft position encoder are used with an AVL 621 Indicom module for high-speed data acquisition (HSDA). In addition to laboratory-grade air flow and fuel flow measurements, a full complement of emission analyzers are available. In this study, two channels of a Cambustion NDIR (nondispersive infrared sensor) Fast CO2 analyzer are utilized, with one in the intake manifold and the other in the exhaust pipe. Also used are CAI (california analytical instruments (a company)) NDIR, HCLD (heated chemi-luminescence detector), and HFID (heated flame ionization detector) analyzers for exhaust CO2, NOx, and total unburned hydrocarbons, respectively. A wide-band O2 sensor is also present in the exhaust.

The aforementioned equipment, full access to the engine control module (ECM), and additional temperature and pressure sensors are integrated using a dSpace system. The dSpace system simultaneously controls the VVA system, sends and receives commands and data with the ECM, and samples all of the external measurement channels.

sec.title: ECR
sec.p: The nominal geometric compression ratio (GCR) of an engine is defined as the ratio of the cylinder volume at bottom dead center (BDC) to the cylinder volume at TDC

This definition of the compression ratio assumes that the engine’s various valve events begin and end precisely at BDC and TDC, which is not the case for most engines in use today. To accommodate different valve timings, the geometric effective compression ratio (GECR) is defined as

where
V
IVC
is the volume of the cylinder when the intake valve closes, whether before or after BDC, and gives a more accurate representation of the in-cylinder compression process due to piston motion. However, this form of the compression ratio is purely geometric and fails to account for flow momentum-induced compression,33 in which the momentum of the charge gas flow drives more mass into the cylinder, actually compressing the charge independent of the piston. Additionally, there is a finite restriction across the intake valve, such that for late IVC timings, the charge is slightly compressed by the upward piston motion, even while the intake valve is still open.

This study utilizes the definition of a pressure-based ECR, which more accurately represents the total in-cylinder compression process, especially in the presence of intake valve modulation.34,35 It captures both piston- and momentum-induced compression of the in-cylinder charge. The ECR is related to an effective IVC volume

where
V
IVC , eff
is the cylinder volume at which the compression process first raises the in-cylinder pressure above the intake manifold pressure, designating an ‘effective’ IVC timing. Figure 3 presents a P–V diagram plotted on logarithmic scales. Notice the discrepancy between the IVC volume
V
IVC
and the volume at the effective IVC
V
IVC , eff
, which is where the cylinder pressure first rises above the intake manifold pressure. The ECR can be calculated using data from an in-cylinder pressure transducer or can be estimated from stock engine sensors using a high-gain observer36 without an in-cylinder pressure transducer.

caption.p: Log scale P–V diagram with early IVC timing.

sec.p: Note that it is possible for the ECR to exceed the geometric compression ratio of 17.3. As the charge will experience piston-induced compression of 17.3:1 (at nominal IVC timings), any additional momentum-induced compression that occurs will add to this, increasing the total amount of compression done on the charge. The maximum ECR seen in this study is 18.2:1.
This definition of ECR creates a direct relationship between the intake manifold conditions and any point of the compression process. Assuming polytropic compression
and the ideal gas law allows computation of the in-cylinder pressure and bulk gas temperature at the ith crank angle along the compression process

where
P
IM
is the intake manifold pressure,
m
charge
is the mass of charge in the cylinder,
R
charge
is the gas constant for the charge, and
n
p
is the polytropic constant. The quantities
R
charge
and
n
p
are taken to be constant at 0.2874 kJ/kg-K and 1.35, respectively, and are calculated from experimental data.

sec.title: Combustion timing model
sec.p: The time delay that exists between the ECM-commanded start of fuel injection (SOIecm) and the SOC is modeled as three distinct, consecutive delays

where
τ
elec
is the delay present in the electrical system,
τ
hyd
is the hydraulic delay present in the injector, and
τ
id
is the ignition delay. This model can be implemented in units of time (ms) or crank angle (°CA).

sec.title:
Electrical delay
τ
elec
sec.p:
Analysis of the injector current signal reveals a difference between the ECM-commanded SOI timing and when the injector current actually begins to rise, as demonstrated in Figure 4. This difference varies between 1.0 and 1.4°CA in the experimental data, with an average of 1.2°CA. This average value is the electrical delay
τ
elec

with engine speed
ω
in rev/min.

caption.p: Electrical delay between ECM-commanded SOI and actual injector current signal.
cad = crank angle degrees.

sec.p: A portion of this electrical delay is attributed to the electrical system dynamics themselves and the rest to an offset in TDC. The TDC offset is the discrepancy between where the engine’s crankshaft position sensor thinks TDC is located (and on which SOIecm is based) and the actual TDC location. Use of the AVL 365C position encoder with 0.1°CA resolution (on which the HSDA is based) allows precise knowledge of the true TDC location. This small offset between the position sensor and encoder then leads the ECM to send the current signal to the injector slightly later, causing part of the observed delay. As the effect of the TDC offset manifests itself in the injector current signal, it is included as part of the ‘electrical’ delay.

sec.title:
Hydraulic delay
τ
hyd
sec.p: The next delay in the system is a hydraulic delay in the injector, which is the time between when the injector current signal is enabled and when fuel droplets actually begin exiting the injector nozzle. Injection rateshape profiles provided by the project sponsor, Cummins Inc., allowed characterization of the hydraulic delay for a variety of engine speed and load conditions. The hydraulic delay is essentially constant in the time domain at 0.3 ms, as illustrated in Figure 5, with

with engine speed
ω
in r/min.

caption.p:
Hydraulic delay between injector current rise and positive fuel rate. Injector current is switched on at
t = 0
ms.

sec.title:
Ignition delay
τ
id
sec.p: Characterization of the electrical and hydraulic delays results in knowledge of the true SOI. The ignition delay is defined as the delay between the true SOI and SOC. In this study, SOC is defined as the location of the minimum of the integrated apparent heat release rate (AHRR) curve. This metric is chosen for SOC because vaporization of the injected fuel will drive the integrated AHRR curve to its minimum, and any subsequent increase from that minimum signifies that positive heat release is occurring and the combustion reaction has initiated.

As discussed in the introduction, some prior efforts have demonstrated the importance of the amount of intake O2 in characterizing PCCI combustion and performance, particularly during transient operation. However, prior efforts to model ignition delay have not always included the effects of in-cylinder diluents such as EGR, residual burned gas, and backflow into the cylinder during valve overlap. Analysis of the experimental data in this work indicates that the ignition delay has strong dependence on both the amount of O2 available and the amount of diluent in the cylinder. To capture these effects, the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction is defined as

where
m
O
2
, total
is the total mass of O2 in the cylinder and
m
charge , total
is the total mass of charge (fresh air, EGR, residual, and backflow) in the cylinder. This total in-cylinder O2 fraction metric will capture changes in both the in-cylinder O2 and in-cylinder diluent (via the
m
charge , total
term).
The EGR, residual, and backflow of exhaust gases will contain some amount of O2 during lean operation, which contributes to the total mass of O2 in the cylinder. The total mass of O2 is

where
m
FAF
is the mass of fresh air,
m
EGR
is the mass of EGR,
χ
O
2
, int
is the oxygen fraction in the intake manifold,
m
res
is the mass of residual burned gas in the cylinder,
m
back
is the mass of burned gas that backflows into the cylinder during valve overlap, and
χ
O
2
, exh
is the oxygen fraction in the exhaust manifold. Accordingly, the total mass of charge is

In this study, the fresh air flow and EGR flow are experimentally measured values. The oxygen fractions in the intake and exhaust manifolds are also experimentally measured using the oxygen sensor and CO2 analyzers. The residual and backflow, however, are not conveniently measured and therefore are modeled using the ideal gas law35

Three assumptions are made. First, the temperature of the residual or reinducted exhaust gases,
T
exh
, is the same as that of the gas in the exhaust manifold,
T
EM
. Secondly, prior to IVO, the exhaust valve is open, such that the in-cylinder pressure will be similar to the exhaust manifold pressure,
P
EM
. Thus, the in-cylinder pressure when the intake valve begins to open,
P
IVO
, is approximated as
P
EM
. Lastly, when the exhaust valve closes, the intake valve is still fully open, such that the in-cylinder pressure will be similar to the intake manifold pressure,
P
IM
. Thus, the in-cylinder pressure at EVC,
P
EVC
, is approximated as
P
IM
. With these assumptions, equations (25) and (27) become

The three assumptions allow definition of the residual and backflow in terms of the intake and exhaust manifold conditions as opposed to in-cylinder conditions, utilizing common manifold sensors in lieu of an in-cylinder pressure transducer. The quantity
R
exh
is taken to be constant at 0.2866 kJ/kg-K and is calculated from experimental data. Cases with negative valve overlap are taken to have
m
back
= 0
.

As described previously, the ignition delay is often modeled using an Arrhenius-type correlation in which the usual pre-exponential constant
A
exp
is broken into two separate factors of A and
ϕ

The model form in equation (30) is modified here to include dependence on the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction
χ

instead of the fuel/air equivalence ratio

. This includes in the correlation the influence of changes in the total in-cylinder O2 and the total in-cylinder diluent. The model form becomes
Defining the average pressure and temperature over the ignition delay period of SOI to SOC can be somewhat ambiguous. Ideally

However, the purpose of the overall model is to predict SOC, such that this value is not known a priori to be used with SOI in determining
P
¯
and
T
¯
in equations (32) and (33). Prior efforts have suggested TDC as an appropriate surrogate for SOC;25 however, in this study, the early-injection PCCI combustion commonly begins well before TDC such that using this as the surrogate is less desirable. An improvement would be to compute the averages between SOI and
− 11 ∘
CA, where
− 11 ∘
CA is the average SOC of the experimental data but only known by virtue of post-processing the data. This too is quite arbitrary and a more generalizable surrogate is needed. Analysis of the experimental data shows that the SOC tends to fall roughly halfway between SOI and TDC as

The accuracy of these three surrogates in representing SOC is presented in Figure 6. Note that the experimental SOC values are included for reference. The surrogate in equation (34) is clearly the best representation of the actual SOC and its trends, and it has dependence on SOI which is known to strongly influence the SOC. Combining equation (34) with equations (32) and (33) gives a useful definition of the average pressure and temperature as

Table 1 summarizes the inputs to the model. The inputs can be measurements, mapped values, output from a dynamic estimator, output from another model, or otherwise.

caption.p: List of model inputs.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The model detailed above is experimentally validated against 180 PCCI data points collected on the experimental engine testbed. SOIecm and IVC (hence ECR) sweeps were performed at 12 nominal speed– load conditions, namely 271, 203, and 102 Nm (200, 150, 75 ft-lbs), each at 2400, 2000, 1600, and 1200 r/min. The VGT position was varied to provide sufficient EGR to remain in a PCCI combustion mode. Figure 7 presents the locations of the data points on the engine’s speed– torque map, and Figure 8 displays the variation in SOIecm, ECR, and VGT position for the data set. Table 2 presents the range of experimental data. All data points presented in this study have a single main injection of fuel and have carbon balance error less than ±10%. Note that all timings are reported in °CA after TDC of firing.

caption.p: Locations of experimental PCCI data on the speed– torque map.
Variation in SOIecm, ECR, and VGT position across the experimental data set.
Range of select variables in experimental data.

sec.p: The locations of the experimental data points displayed in Figure 7 represent the full operating range of PCCI combustion possible on this experimental testbed with the stock EGR, VGT, and SOIecm actuators and IVC modulation.

Figure 9 presents a comparison of the
τ
id
model in equation (39) versus the experimental data. The model predicts the ignition delay within ±2°CA of the experimental values for all but three of the 180 data points. Note that the experimental ignition delays range from as small as 3.6°CA to as large as 13.3°CA, and that the error between the model and experimental ignition delay is also included in Figure 9. Figure 10 shows the same model and experimental data in a scatter plot for comparison. The solid line is the 1:1 line and the dashed lines signify ±2°CA.

caption.p:

sec.p:
The PCCI combustion timing model in equation (40) maps from SOIecm to SOC given knowledge of total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction
χ
O
2
, the average pressure and temperature across the ignition delay
P
¯
,
T
¯
, and engine speed
ω
. Figure 11 presents a comparison of the PCCI combustion timing model’s prediction of SOC versus the experimental SOC data. The model predicts the SOC within ±2°CA of the experimental values for all but three of the 180 data points, which represents 98%+ accuracy. The root mean square (RMS) error is 0.86°CA. Note that the experimental SOC ranges from as early as −19.3°CA to as late as +0.6°CA by heavily exercising the control authority over SOC provided by SOIecm, ECR/IVC modulation, and the engine’s air-handling system. Figure 12 shows the same model and experimental SOC data in a scatter plot for comparison. The solid line is the 1:1 line and the dashed lines signify ±2°CA.

caption.p: Model versus experimental SOC.
cad = crank angle degrees.
Scatter plot of model versus experimental SOC (dashed lines are ±2°CA).
cad = crank angle degrees.

sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the variation and influence of the three model inputs (
P
¯
,
T
¯
, and
χ
O
2
) on the ignition delay. Clearly these three inputs have direct and strong influence on the ignition delay process. An increase in temperature causes a reduction in ignition delay. As the bulk temperature of the in-cylinder charge increases, the kinetic energy (translational, rotational, and vibrational) of each individual gas molecule is increased, resulting in more energetic collisions between molecules. This gives an improved chance that a collision between fuel and O2 molecules will be energetic enough to break chemical bonds, and that enough bond-breaking collisions occur in a given time or space to initiate a chemical reaction. Chain propagating and chain branching reactions are accelerated by increases in temperature, such that the build up of radicals prior to the SOC happens faster, reducing the ignition delay. In contrast, reducing temperature will lengthen the ignition delay.

caption.p:
Variation of direct inputs to the
τ
id
model with
τ
id
in ms,
T
¯
in K,
P
¯
in bar, and
χ
O
2
has no units (model data is solid, experimental data is dashed).

sec.p: An increase in in-cylinder pressure also reduces the ignition delay period. Increased pressure of the charge gas signifies an increase in the translational kinetic energy of the molecules, again leading to more energetic collisions and a better chance for a sustained reaction. A rise in pressure also signifies an increase in density or concentration of the charge gas molecules, such that the probability and frequency of molecular collisions is greatly increased as there are more molecules per unit volume. By the same means, lower pressures will decrease the energy of collisions and reduce the probability and frequency of collisions, increasing the ignition delay.

Increases in the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction shortens the ignition delay as more O2 molecules are present or are less inhibited by molecules of diluent to find and react with fuel. Also, less diluent in the cylinder will reduce the number of non-participating molecules that act as energy sinks and inhibit reaction propagation. Decreases (less O2 and/or more diluent) lengthen the delay. This inverse relationship between
χ
O
2
and
τ
id
, as well as the inverse relationship between
P
¯
and
τ
id
and the inverse exponential relationship between
T
¯
and
τ
id
are all captured in the model.

sec.title: Results – actuator sweeps
sec.p:
The three inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model (
P
¯
,
T
¯
, and
χ
O
2
) can be directly and indirectly influenced by four ‘actuators’ on the engine, namely the VGT position, EGR valve position, and IVC timing, which all relate to the gas exchange process, as well as the SOIecm timing, a command given to the fuel system. The previous section shows results for experimental data where as many as three of these actuators were being modulated at once. The following experimental results show the performance of the combustion timing model when only one of the control actuators is being varied at a time. The primary purpose of the following is to establish the ‘control authority’ over the SOC timing. In Figures 15–24 the dashed lines represent experimental data and the solid lines are model variables.

sec.title: EGR position
sec.p: The pressure difference between the manifolds is what drives EGR flow from the exhaust manifold through a crossover pipe and into the intake manifold. There are two primary means to regulate the amount of EGR flow in an engine. First, an electronically controlled EGR valve is located in the crossover pipe, acting as a variable orifice. Modulation of the EGR valve position varies the effective flow area of the orifice, in turn controlling the amount of burned gas that flows from the exhaust manifold to the intake. The engine schematic in Figure 1 displays this architecture.

Additionally, the VGT position can influence the amount of EGR flow. Closing the VGT increases the flow restriction through the turbine, which increases the exhaust manifold pressure significantly (while providing somewhat less turbocharger boost to increase the intake manifold pressure). This increases the pressure differential between the exhaust and intake manifolds and ultimately drives more EGR flow. Opening the VGT has the opposite effect. This complex, nonlinear relationship between the EGR valve position and VGT position is detailed in Modiyani et al.37 and Kocher et al.,38 and is illustrated in Figure 14. The red curves represent VGT position sweeps at three fixed EGR valve positions, and the black curves represent EGR valve position sweeps at three fixed VGT positions. Closing the VGT with the EGR valve held constant increases the exhaust manifold pressure, driving more EGR flow as evidenced by the increase in EGR fraction. The higher exhaust manifold pressure increases the turbine and compressor power for increased fresh air flow, which, along with the increase in EGR flow, results in an increase in charge flow. As the VGT becomes more and more closed, the EGR fraction continues to increase, but at a certain point, the turbine reaches a peak in efficiency. Closing the VGT beyond this point causes the turbine to develop less power to drive the compressor, which reduces the fresh air flow and charge flow. This is evident in Figure 14, where each of the red curves shows increasing charge flow, reaches a peak, and then changes direction toward reduced charge flow while the EGR fraction increases. Opening the EGR valve with the VGT held constant, as shown in the black curves, clearly increases the EGR fraction but also slightly reduces the charge flow. This effect is due to more of the charge mass flow being composed of hot EGR gases instead of the cool, dense fresh air flow. Opening the EGR valve will decrease the exhaust manifold pressure, reducing turbine power and subsequently decreasing the amount of fresh air flow.

caption.p: Nominal air-handling actuator sweeps with experimental VGT sweep shown.

sec.p: In this study, the EGR valve is set fully open for all experimental cases. In many situations, the limiting factor to achieve a PCCI combustion event is driving enough EGR to sufficiently dilute the in-cylinder charge to provide a long enough ignition delay for full premixing. Any modulation to the EGR valve (from the fully open position) will increase the restriction in the crossover pipe and reduce the EGR flow, which is undesirable.

sec.title: VGT position
sec.p: A sweep of 12 different VGT positions was performed. The remaining actuators and commands were held constant, including engine speed at 1600 r/min, total fueling of 25.8 mg/stroke (nominally 203 Nm, 150 ft-lbs), SOIecm of −30°CA, EGR position at 100% open, and an IVC timing of −185°CA. The results are presented in Figures 15,16, and 17.

caption.p:
Effect of VGT position sweep on ignition delay and the direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model, with VGT position in % closed,
τ
id
in °CA,
χ
O
2
has no units,
P
¯
in bar, and
T
¯
in K.

Effect of VGT position sweep on select engine parameters, with VGT position in % closed,
m
chg , tot
in mg/stroke, ECR has no units,
T
IM
in K, and
m
·
in kg/min.
Model versus experimental SOC for VGT position sweep.

sec.p:
Figure 15 illustrates the VGT position sweep and its effect on ignition delay and the three direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model,
χ
O
2
,
P
¯
, and
T
¯
. At the beginning of the VGT position sweep, small changes in VGT position cause a larger decrease in the ignition delay, whereas at the end of the sweep, larger changes in VGT position cause little change in the ignition delay. This reveals the complex, nonlinear relationship that exists between the VGT position actuator and the ignition delay process. Overall, opening the VGT position shortens the ignition delay. At the beginning of the sweep where the VGT position is the most closed, the exhaust manifold pressure is at its highest, driving very large amounts of EGR, which dilutes the charge and lengthens the ignition delay. As the VGT opens, the exhaust manifold pressure decreases, reducing the amount of EGR, which is then replaced by fresh air. With less diluent and more O2 in the cylinder, the ignition delay decreases. The total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction in Figure 15 demonstrates this, as
χ
O
2
steadily increases as the VGT position is opened.

Figure 15 shows that the average pressure over the ignition delay
P
¯
increases as the VGT is opened, also contributing to the reduction in ignition delay. The average temperature of the ignition delay
T
¯
, however, surprisingly decreases, which is not expected as the model in equation (31) shows that an increase in temperature should lead to exponentially shorter ignition delays. Figure 16 shows that the total in-cylinder charge mass,
m
charge , tot
, and the ECR both increase across the sweep, which is consistent with the increase in
P
¯
. As more charge mass is present in the cylinder, compression pressures will increase. A larger mass flow of charge will have more momentum, increasing the momentum-induced compression in the cylinder prior to IVC, raising the ECR. However, for increased charge mass and more compression, intuitively the
T
¯
whould increase instead of decrease. To explain this, Figure 16 shows that the intake manifold temperature decreases across the sweep, which will lower compression temperatures and hence
T
¯
. The decrease in intake manifold temperature is due to the VGT position’s effect on EGR. As the VGT position is opened and the exhaust manifold pressure reduces, less EGR flow is driven from the exhaust to the intake, being replaced in the intake with more fresh air flow from the compressor. This effect is seen in the plot of flows in Figure 16. The VGT position opens, which reduces the amount of hot EGR flowing into the intake, increasing the amount of cool, dense fresh air flow into the intake, ultimately reducing the intake manifold temperature and hence the average temperature
T
¯
. In this case, the increases in in-cylinder O2 and average pressure
P
¯
outweighthe decrease in
T
¯
to shorten the ignition delay. The model successfully captures all of these effects and predicts the ignition delay well within ±2°CA.

Figures 15 and 16 show that the average pressure
P
¯
and total charge mass
m
charge , tot
increase as the VGT is opened, reach a maximum, and then decrease slightly. This is a function of the turbocharger efficiency.38 Refer to the location and direction of the experimental VGT sweep (shown with solid line) in Figure 14. At the extremely closed VGT positions needed to drive sufficient EGR for PCCI combustion, the turbine is inefficient and develops little power for the flow restriction it causes. As the VGT position is opened, the restriction decreases and the turbine operates more efficiently. This increases turbine power and drives more fresh air through the compressor, increasing charge mass and in-cylinder pressures. A maximum is reached at peak efficiency, after which the turbine is open to the point it engages less of the exhaust flow, also reducing the power it develops. This causes the slight reduction in
P
¯
and
m
charge , tot
seen in Figures 15 and 16 at the end of the sweep. The average temperature
T
¯
also experiences this phenomenon, reacting in an inverse manner. Again, the model successfully captures these effects during the VGT position sweep.

The nonlinear relationship between the experimental and predicted SOC and VGT position is characterized in Figure 17, which is very similar to that of the ignition delay described earlier. Varying the VGT position over its full effective range (for PCCI combustion) at this engine speed and load between 93% and 61% closed can shift the SOC by up to 4.1°CA. The model predicts the SOC to within ±1.1°CA during the VGT position sweep, well within the ±2°CA bound. VGT sweeps at other engine speeds and loads will have generally different VGT position ranges and control authority over the flows, yet all trends and relationships described here, as well as the model’s ability to capture them, are expected to be the same within the PCCI operating space represented in Figure 7.

sec.title: IVC timing
sec.p: A sweep of 12 different IVC timings was performed. The remaining actuators and commands were held constant, including engine speed at 1600 r/min, total fueling of 37 mg/stroke (nominally 271 Nm, 200 ft-lbs), SOIecm of −30°CA, EGR position at 100% open, and a VGT position of 75% closed. The results are presented in Figures 18–21.

caption.p:
Effect of IVC timing sweep on ignition delay and the direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model, with IVC timing and

id
in °CA,

O
2
has no units,

¯
in bar, and
T
¯
in K.
Effect of IVC timing sweep on ECR and total EGR fraction.

Effect of IVC timing sweep on amounts of charge and oxygen, with IVC timing in °CA,
m
chg , tot
and
m
O
2
, tot
in mg/stroke, and
χ
O
2
, exh
and
χ
O
2
, int
in % mass.
Model versus experimental SOC for IVC timing sweep.

sec.p:
Figure 18 presents the effect of the IVC timing sweep on the ignition delay and the three direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model,
χ
O
2
,
P
¯
, and
T
¯
. The ignition delay steadily increases because the average pressure
P
¯
, average temperature
T
¯
, and the total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction
χ
O
2
all simultaneously decrease as the IVC timing is moved earlier.

Moving the IVC timing earlier in this sweep corresponds to a reduction in the ECR as shown in Figure 19. The ECR decreases from 18.2 to 13.9:1 across the sweep, resulting in reduced compression of the in-cylinder gases. Utilizing the definition of ECR given in equation (12), this reduction in ECR corresponds to a reduction in
V
IVC , eff
, the cylinder volume at the effective IVC timing. Starting compression at a smaller cylinder volume results in less compression of the in-cylinder mass, leading to lower in-cylinder pressure and bulk gas temperature by virtue of the polytropic compression equations (15) and (16), as shown for
P
¯
and
T
¯
in Figure 18.

The total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction
χ
O
2
decreases by 1.5% across this IVC sweep, yet the total in-cylinder EGR mass fraction (which includes EGR, residual, and backflow), shown in Figure 19, remains constant. One would expect the total in-cylinder EGR mass fraction to increase by greater than 1.5% to achieve this reduction in oxygen mass fraction. As the EGR, residual, and backflow contain some oxygen during lean operation, a 1.5% increase in total EGR mass would replace somewhat less than 1.5% (by mass) of oxygen. Thus, the increase in total in-cylinder EGR mass fraction must be greater than 1.5% to cause the observed reduction in the oxygen mass fraction, yet no increase is observed. The difference is made up by the fact that although the total in-cylinder EGR mass fraction does not change itself, the composition of the EGR, residual, and backflow gases is changing during this sweep.

Figure 20 shows that the charge mass
m
charge , tot
decreases with earlier IVC timings. This is expected, as closing the intake valve early before the piston motion and fluid momentum can fully fill the cylinder will reduce the amount of trapped charge mass. Less charge mass also means there is a lower mass of oxygen in the cylinder, yet the fueling remains constant across this IVC sweep. Thus, with decreasing amounts of oxygen in the cylinder but the same amount of oxygen needed to burn the fixed fuel mass, there is less oxygen left over in the burned gases. This is shown in Figure 20, as the oxygen mass fraction in the exhaust manifold
χ
O
2
, exh
decreases by 4.5% across the sweep. This burned gas containing less oxygen is recirculated to the intake manifold as EGR, thus explaining the reduction of 1.2% seen in the oxygen mass fraction in the intake manifold
χ
O
2
, int
. The end result is that the composition of the EGR, residual, and backflow in the cylinder contains less oxygen, contributing to the reduction in the total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction. The model successfully captures all of these effects and predicts the ignition delay within ±1.0°CA.

Figure 21 illustrates the strong inverse relationship between the SOC timing and IVC timing (hence the ECR). Whereas the VGT position has significant control authority over the total in-cylinder oxygen mass fraction
χ
O
2
, as shown in Figure 15, the IVC timing has significant control authority over the average in-cylinder pressure
P
¯
and temperature
T
¯
as shown in Figure 18. Varying the IVC timing over its full effective range (for PCCI combustion) at this engine speed and load between
− 155
(nominal) and
− 210 ∘
CA (18.2 and 13.9:1 ECR) can shift the SOC by up to 3.0°CA. The model predicts the SOC to within
± 1 . 0 ∘
CA during the IVC timing sweep. IVC sweeps at other engine speeds and loads will have generally different ECRs and control authority over the compression process. For example, the same IVC timing sweep performed at 2000 r/min and a fueling of 32.1 mg/stroke (nominally 203 Nm, 150 ft-lbs) shifted the SOC by up to 6.2°CA, more than double the change seen here. At other engine speeds and loads, all of the trends and relationships described here, as well as the model’s ability to capture them, are expected to be the same within the PCCI operating space represented in Figure 7.

sec.title: SOIecm timing
sec.p: A sweep of six different SOIecm timings was performed. The remaining actuators and commands were held constant, including engine speed at 1200 r/min, total fueling of 28.0 mg/stroke (nominally 203 Nm, 150 ft-lbs), VGT position of 89% closed, EGR position at 100% open, and an IVC timing of −185°CA. The results are presented in Figures 22, 23, and 24.

caption.p:
Effect of SOIecm timing sweep on ignition delay and the direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model, with SOIecm and
τ
id
in °CA,
χ
O
2
has no units,
P
¯
in bar, and
T
¯
in K.

Effect of SOIecm timing sweep on the gas exchange process, with SOIecm in °CA,
m
chg , tot
in mg/stroke, EGR in % mass, and
P
EM
and
P
IM
in kPa.
Model versus experimental SOC for SOIecm timing sweep.

sec.p:
Figure 22 presents the effect of the SOIecm timing sweep on the ignition delay and the three direct inputs to the PCCI combustion timing model,
χ
O
2
,
P
¯
, and
T
¯
. As SOIecm moves later and hence closer to TDC, the ignition delay steadily decreases. The total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction
χ
O
2
has negligible change, which is expected as varying the SOIecm changes when the fuel is injected, but should have little effect on the total mass of charge in the cylinder or its composition. The average pressure
P
¯
and average temperature
T
¯
during the ignition delay period both increase steadily. As the injection timing moves incrementally closer to TDC, the ignition delay period takes place further along the compression process such that the in-cylinder pressures and temperatures will be higher. These increased temperatures and pressures will decrease the ignition delay, as evidenced in Figure 22. The model successfully captures these intuitive effects and predicts the ignition delay well within ±2°CA.

From the perspective of combustion efficiency, it is possible that the most optimal SOIecm timing would have a more efficient combustion event in terms of energy release, resulting in increased in-cylinder pressure and temperature. This will increase the enthalpy of the post-combustion and post-expansion gases, which will influence the turbocharger and the gas exchange process.39 Figure 23 demonstrates exactly this effect. As the SOIecm timing moves the actual combustion event closer to TDC, the exhaust manifold pressure increases slightly. This in turn drives more EGR, raises the intake manifold pressure, and increases the total charge mass. However, the magnitudes of these changes are so small across a large span of SOIecm timings that they are practically negligible. So although there are these minor effects occuring within the gas exchange process during changes in SOIecm timing, they are insignificant compared to the much larger changes in
P
¯
and
T
¯
and thus have no appreciable influence on the ignition delay or SOC.

The relationship between SOC timing and SOIecm timing is presented in Figure 24. A linear change in SOIecm results in an almost linear change in SOC timing. Varying the SOIecm timing over its full effective range (for PCCI combustion on this testbed) between −30°CA and −10°CA can shift the SOC by up to 16.8°CA, from −18.5 to −1.7°CA. This demonstrates the strong influence that the injection timing has on the SOC timing. It is interesting to observe that during this SOIecm timing sweep, the ignition delay only varies by 3.2°CA, yet the SOC timing varies by 16.8°CA. This illustrates that the significant pressure and temperature changes caused by changes in the SOIecm timing have a smaller effect on SOC than the actual placement of the injection itself. Whereas the VGT, EGR, and IVC actuators influence the gas exchange process to change the SOC via temperature, pressure, and composition of the charge, the SOIecm timing itself has a direct influence on the SOC timing, with the resulting effects on the gas exchange process assuming a smaller role.

The model predicts the SOC to within ±0.4°CA during the SOIecm sweep, well within the ±2°CA bound. The control authority of SOIecm timing sweeps at other engine speeds and loads may be somewhat different in magnitude, but all trends and relationships described here, as well as the model’s ability to capture them, are expected to be the same within the PCCI operating space represented in Figure 7.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This study presents a simple, analytical, control-oriented model for prediction of the SOC timing in PCCI combustion. It is a single expression with only three fitted constants and is specifically developed to include explicit dependence on the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction introduced in this study, which captures changes in the amount of in-cylinder O2 and in-cylinder diluent. It is cast in an analytical form by utilizing definitions of in-cylinder temperature and pressure as averages over the ignition delay period between SOI and the variable upper limit of
1
2
( SOI − TDC )
. It is extensively validated with 180 PCCI experimental points collected on a multi-cylinder diesel engine testbed utilizing flexible intake valve modulation. Inputs and factors that influence the combustion timing, such as SOIecm, IVC/ECR modulation, in-cylinder pressure and temperature, and the total in-cylinder O2 mass fraction are all exercised over a large range of values to fully evaluate the model’s accuracy. The model predicts the SOC within ±2°CA for all but three of the 180 data points (98%+ accuracy), with an RMS error of 0.86°CA.

Sweeps are performed for each individual control actuator (with the other control actuators held constant) to characterize the effect and control authority of each actuator on the ignition delay and SOC, as well as the model’s ability to predict it. The folowing results are obtained.

list-item.p: The SOI command from the ECM, SOIecm, has a large and direct effect on the SOC timing, as expected. Whereas the other actuators affect the gas exchange process to subsequently change the SOC timing, the actual placement of the start of the fuel injection directly impacts the location of SOC. The model predicts the SOC within ±0.4°CA of the experimental values during the SOIecm sweep, and accurately captures the trends in in-cylinder pressure and temperature.

The VGT position actuator has a strong influence on the entire gas exchange process, particularly on the amount of O2 and diluent in the cylinder by means of EGR. The model predicts the SOC within ±1.1°CA of the experimental values during the VGT position sweep, and accurately captures the trends in in-cylinder pressure and temperature.

Modulation of the ECR via the IVC timing command has a profound effect on the in-cylinder pressure and bulk gas temperature by varying the amount of compression, which directly affects the ignition delay process and the SOC timing. It is highly coupled with the gas exchange process and can vary the amount of trapped mass in the cylinder as well as the composition of the EGR, residual, and backflow. The model predicts the strong inverse relationship between IVC timing and SOC within ±1.0°CA of the experimental values during the IVC timing sweep, and accurately captures the trends in in-cylinder pressure and temperature.

The control authority over the SOC timing provided by these actuators and commands when swept across their effective operating ranges for PCCI combustion at the specified engine speeds and loads are displayed in Table 3.

It is clear that SOIecm has the most direct influence on the SOC timing. The IVC timing has strong control authority over the in-cylinder pressure and temperature, which can change the SOC timing on the same order of magnitude as the VGT position, which has strong control authority over the amount of in-cylinder oxygen and diluent.

caption.p: Control authority over SOC.

sec.p: Overall, this simple, analytical, physically based and control-oriented model for prediction of the SOC timing in PCCI combustion successfully captures the relevant trends and timings for characterization of the SOC timing and how to influence it.

ack.p: Special thanks to Cummins, Inc. for providing the engine and other experimental equipment, as well as technical support, especially from the following researchers at Cummins Technical Center in Columbus, Indiana: Ray Shute, Tim Frazier, Cheryl Klepser, Don Stanton, Phanindra Garimella, and Rajani Modiyani. Special thanks to AVL North America, Inc. for providing the use of an AVL 621 Indimodul. The authors also wish to thank the Technical Services staff at the Ray W. Herrick Laboratories for their assistance: B. Brown, G. Gordon and F. Lee.
